computers such as the msnbc cable television network the msn internet portal and the microsoft encarta multimedia encyclopedia the company also markets
computers markets both computer hardware products such as the microsoft mouse as well as home entertainment products such as the xbox xbox
computers xbox and msn tv microsoft s name originally bi capitalized as microsoft or with hyphenation as micro soft is a portmanteau
computers portmanteau of microcomputer software and is often abbreviated as ms the company was founded in albuquerque new mexico on april by
computers by bill gates and paul allen to develop and sell basic interpreters for the altair after the market saw a flood
computers flood of ibm pc clones in the mid s microsoft used its new position which it gained in part due to
computers to a contract from ibm to dominate the home computer operating system market with ms dos which stood for microsoft disk
computers disk operating system the company later released an initial public offering ipo in the stock market which netted several of its
computers its employees millions of dollars due to the ensuing rise of the stock price the price of the stock continued its
computers its rise steadily into the early s in microsoft windows originally an add on for ms dos the company was selling
computers selling what would become the most widely used operating system in the world microsoft continued to push into multiple markets such
computers such as computer hardware and television in addition microsoft has historically given customer support over usenet newsgroups and the world wide
computers wide web and awards microsoft mvp status to volunteers who are deemed helpful in assisting the company s customers with what
computers what is generally described as a developer centric business culture microsoft has become widely known for some of its internal codes
computers codes of conduct for its employees one example is the principle eat your own dog food which describes the practice of
computers of using pre release products inside the company to test them in an environment geared towards the real world microsoft has
computers has been convicted of monopolistic business practices the u s justice department among others has sued microsoft for antitrust violations and
computers and software bundling the slogan embrace extend and extinguish is often used to describe microsoft s strategy for entering product categories
computers categories involving widely used standards extending those standards with proprietary capabilities and then using those differences to disadvantage its competitors in
computers in addition microsoft has been criticized for the insecurity of its software however microsoft has won several awards such as the
computers the most innovative company operating in the u s by fortune magazine as well as maintaining a place on the fortune

computers competition that does not or cannot use microsoft s new version these and other tactics have led to various companies and
computers and governments filing lawsuits against microsoft microsoft has been called a velvet sweatshop in reference to allegations of the company working

computers c pronounced see plus plus ipa si pl s pl s is a general purpose high level language with low level
computers level facilities it is a statically typed free form multi paradigm language supporting procedural data abstraction object oriented programming generic programming
computers programming and rtti since the s c has been one of the most popular commercial programming languages bjarne stroustrup developed c
computers c originally named c with classes in at bell labs as an enhancement to the c language enhancements started with the
computers the addition of classes ed by among other features virtual functions operator overloading multiple inheritance templates and exception handling the c
computers c programming language standard was ratified in as iso iec the current version of which is the version iso iec a
computers a new version of the standard known informally as c x is being developed contents history the name c future development

computers see also more information miscellaneous references external links materials tutorials electronic books support other libraries and code repositories history stroustrup began
computers began work on c with classes in the idea of creating a new language originated from stroustrup s experience in for
computers for his ph d thesis stroustrup found that simula had features that were very helpful for large software development but the
computers the language was too slow for practical use while bcpl was fast but too low level and unsuitable for large software
computers software development when stroustrup started working in bell labs he had the problem of analyzing the unix kernel with respect to
computers to distributed computing remembering his ph d experience stroustrup set out to enhance the c language with simula like features c
computers c was chosen because it is general purpose fast and portable besides c and simula some other languages which inspired him
computers him were algol ada clu and ml at first the class derived class strong type checking inlining and default argument features
computers features were added to c via cfront the first commercial release occurred in october in the name of the language was
computers was changed from c with classes to c new features were added including virtual functions function name and operator overloading references
computers references constants user controlled free store memory control improved type checking and a new single line comment style with two forward
computers forward slashes in the first edition of the c language was released providing an important reference to the language as there
computers there was not yet an official standard in release of c was released new features included multiple inheritance abstract classes static
computers static member functions const member functions and protected members in the annotated c reference manual was published this work became the
computers the basis for the future standard late addition of features included templates exceptions namespaces new casts and a boolean type as
computers as the c language evolved a standard library also evolved with it the first addition to the c standard library was
computers was the stream i o library which provided facilities to replace the traditional c functions such as printf and scanf later
computers later among the most significant additions to the standard library was the standard template library after years of work a joint
computers joint ansi iso committee standardized c in iso iec for some years after the official release of the standard in the
computers the committee processed defect reports and published a corrected version of the c standard in in a technical report called the
computers the library technical report often known as tr for short was released while not an official part of the standard it
computers it gives a number of extensions to the standard library which are expected to be included in the next version of
computers of c support for tr is growing in almost all currently maintained c compilers while the c language is royalty free
computers free the standard document itself is not freely available the name c this name is credited to rick mascitti mid and
computers and was first used in december earlier during the research period the developing language had been referred to as new c
computers c then c with classes in computer science c is still referred to as a superstructure of c the final name
computers name stems from c s operator which increments the value of a variable and a common naming convention of using to
computers to indicate an enhanced computer program according to stroustrup the name signifies the evolutionary nature of the changes from c c
computers c was the name of an earlier unrelated language stroustrup addressed the origin of the name in the preface of later
computers later editions of his book the c language adding that c might be inferred from the appendix of george orwell s
computers s nineteen eighty four of the three segments of the fictional language newspeak the c vocabulary is the one dedicated to
computers to technical terms and jargon doubleplus is the superlative modifier for newspeak adjectives thus c might hold the meaning most extremely
computers extremely technical or jargonous in newspeak when rick mascitti was questioned informally in about the naming he indicated that it was
computers was given in a tongue in cheek spirit he never thought that it would become the formal name of the language
computers language a common joke of the name is that in c when you postfix the addition happens only after the operation
computers operation hence it should be c and not c future development c continues to evolve to meet future requirements one group
computers group in particular boost org works to make the most of c in its current form and advises the c standards
computers standards committee as to which features work well and which need improving current work indicates that c will capitalize on its
computers its multi paradigm nature more and more the work at boost for example is greatly expanding c s functional and metaprogramming
computers metaprogramming capabilities a new version of the c standard is currently being worked on entitled c x denoting the fact it
computers it is expected to be released before which will include a number of new features philosophy in the design and evolution
computers evolution of c bjarne stroustrup describes some rules that he uses for the design of c knowing the rules helps to
computers to understand why c is the way it is the ing is a summary of the rules much more detail can
computers can be found in the design and evolution of c c is designed to be a statically typed general purpose language
computers language that is as efficient and portable as c c is designed to directly and comprehensively support multiple styles procedural data
computers data abstraction object oriented programming and generic c is designed to give the programmer choice even if this makes it possible
computers possible for the programmer to choose incorrectly c is designed to be as compatible with c as possible therefore providing a
computers a smooth transition from c c avoids features that are platform specific or not general purpose c does not incur overhead
computers overhead for features that are not used c is designed to function without a sophisticated environment stanley b lippman describes various
computers various models in his in depth book inside the c object model for how compilers may convert c program statements into
computers into an in memory layout compiler vendors are free to implement the standard in their own manner lippman worked on implementing
computers implementing and maintaining cfront the original c implementation at bell labs standard library the c standard consists of two parts the
computers the core language and the c standard library the latter includes most of the standard template library and a slightly modified
computers modified version of the c standard library many c libraries exist which are not part of the standard and using external
computers external linkage libraries can even be in c the c standard library incorporates the c standard library with some small modifications
computers modifications to make it work better with the c language another large part of the c library is based on the
computers the standard template library stl this provides such useful tools as containers for example vectors and lists iterators generalized pointers to
computers to provide these containers with array like access and algorithms to perform operations such as searching and sorting furthermore multi maps
computers maps associative arrays and multi sets are provided all of which export compatible interfaces therefore it is possible using templates to
computers to write generic algorithms that work with any container or on any sequence defined by iterators as in c the features
computers features of the library are accessed by using the include directive to include a standard header c provides sixty nine standard
computers standard headers of which nineteen are deprecated using the standard library for example using std vector or std string instead of
computers of a c style array can help lead to safer and more scalable software the stl was originally a third party
computers party library from hp and later sgi before its incorporation into the c standard the standard does not refer to it
computers it as stl as it is merely a part of the standard library but many people still use that term to
computers to distinguish it from the rest of the library input output streams internationalization diagnostics the c library subset etc most c
computers c compilers provide an implementation of the c standard library including the stl compiler independent implementations of the stl such as
computers as stlport also exist other projects also produce various custom implementations of the c standard library and the stl with various
computers various design goals features introduced in c compared to the c language c introduced extra features including declarations as statements function
computers function like casts new delete bool reference types inline functions default arguments function overloading namespaces classes including all class related features
computers features such as inheritance member functions virtual functions abstract classes and constructors operator overloading templates the operator exception handling and runtime
computers runtime type identification contrary to popular belief c did not introduce the const keyword first const was formally added to c
computers c shortly before it was adopted by c c also performs more type checking than c in several cases see incompatibility
computers incompatibility with c below comments starting with two slashes were originally part of c s predecessor bcpl and were reintroduced in
computers in c several features of c were later adopted by c including declarations in for loops c style comments using the
computers the symbol and inline though the c definition of the inline keyword is not compatible with its c definition however c
computers c also introduced features that do not exist in c such as variadic macros and better handling of arrays as parameters
computers parameters some c compilers may implement some of these features as extensions but others are incompatible with existing c features a
computers a very common source of confusion is a subtle terminology issue because of its derivation from c in c the term
computers term object means memory area just like in c and not class instance which is what it means in most other
computers other object oriented languages for example in both c and c the statement int i defines an object of type int
computers int that is the memory area where the value of the variable i will be stored on assignment incompatibility with c
computers c for more details on this topic see compatibility of c and c c is often considered to be a superset
computers superset of c but this is not strictly true most c code can easily be made to compile correctly in c
computers c but there are a few differences that cause some valid c code to be invalid in c or to behave
computers behave differently in c perhaps the most commonly encountered difference is that c allows implicit conversion from void to other pointer
computers pointer types but c does not so the ing is valid c code int i malloc sizeof int implicit conversion from
computers from void to int but to make it work in both c and c one would need to use an explicit
computers explicit cast int i int malloc sizeof int another common portability issue is that c defines many new keywords such as
computers as new and class that may be used as identifiers e g variable names in a c program some incompatibilities have
computers have been removed by the latest c c standard which now supports c features such as comments and mixed declarations and
computers and code however c introduced a number of new features that conflict with c such as variable length arrays native complex
computers complex number types and compound literals so the languages may be diverging more than they are converging in order to intermix
computers intermix c and c code any c code which is to be called from used in c must be put in
computers in extern c c code sample code minimal program this is an example of a program which does nothing it begins
computers begins executing and immediately terminates it consists of one thing a main function the function main is the designated start of
computers of a c program in more complex c programs code can be executed before main begins for example the constructors of
computers of all global variables are run first there can be only one main function in a program notes on compiler issues
computers issues even though the latest c standard does not require a return in main some older compilers such as microsoft visual
computers visual c give warnings or errors for a main without a return statement and may not generate correct object code int
computers int main the c standard requires that main returns type int a program which uses any other return type for main
computers main is technically not standard c although many compilers do not enforce this strictly the standard also does not say what
computers what the return value of main actually means traditionally it is interpreted as the return value of the program itself the
computers the standard guarantees that returning zero or the macro exit success from main indicates successful termination unsuccessful termination can be indicated
computers indicated by returning the macro exit failure all other values are implementation defined this allows each operating system to define these
computers these values differently if as in this example execution reaches the end of main without encountering a return statement zero is
computers is returned implicitly only the main function has this implicit return statement in any other non void function reaching the end
computers end of the function without meeting a return statement is undefined behavior hello world program this is an example of a
computers a hello world program which uses the c standard library not the standard template library stl cout facility to display a
computers a message then terminates notes on include lt ostream gt an additional include lt ostream gt directive may be necessary with
computers with some obscure c implementations this is due to the fact that while the c iso standard requires that the standard
computers standard header iostream declares the object std cout to be an instance of the standard class ostream it does not demand
computers demand that iostream defines the class std ostream and the operations associated with it include lt iostream gt for std cout
computers cout using namespace std c programmers make use of using namespace lt name gt known as a using directive which imports
computers imports all symbols from the target namespace into the current namespace in this example using namespace std allows for unqualified access
computers access to all the standard library names so that std cout can be shortened to cout widespread use of the global
computers global using namespace directive is generally discouraged because importation of a large number of names may result in global namespace pollution
computers pollution this is especially true in header files which are included across many compilation units for this reason a more restricted
computers restricted using declaration may be used to import only the required names without importing the entire namespace in the example above
computers above the using namespace std may be replaced with using declarations as s using std cout using std endl for more
computers more examples see c examples language features operators main article operators in c and c preprocessor c is principally compiled in
computers in three phases preprocessing translation to object code and linking the two last phases are what is generally thought of as
computers as the compilation proper in the first phase preprocessing preprocessor directives apply lexical transformations to the source code which is then
computers then fed to the next compilation stage preprocessor directives and macros pre processing directives work by simple substitution of tokenized character
computers character sequences for other tokenized character sequences according to user defined rules they typically perform macro substitution inclusion of other files
computers files by opposition to higher order features such as inclusion of modules packages units components conditional compilation and or conditional inclusion
computers inclusion for instance define pi every time pi appears in the source code it will be replaced with another common example
computers example is include lt iostream gt which includes imports all symbols from the standard library header file iostream in addition to
computers to the most common directives mentioned above there are several additional preprocessor directives that control the flow of compilation conditionally include
computers include or exclude code blocks and control various other aspects of compilation also see preprocessor and c preprocessor templates templates are
computers are different from macros while both of these compile time language features can be used to produce conditional compilation templates are
computers are not restricted to lexical substitution templates have an awareness of the semantics and type system of their companion language as
computers as well as all compile time type definitions and can perform high level operations including programmatic flow control based on evaluation
computers evaluation of strictly type checked parameters macros are capable of conditional control over compilation based on predetermined criteria but cannot instantiate
computers instantiate new types recurse or perform type evaluation and in effect are limited to pre compilation text substitution and text inclusion
computers inclusion exclusion in other words macros can control compilation flow based on pre defined symbols but cannot unlike templates independently instantiate
computers instantiate new symbols templates are a tool for static polymorphism see below and generic this can be found in the algorithm
computers algorithm header as std max in addition templates are a compile time mechanism in c which is turing complete meaning that
computers that any computation expressible by a computer program can be computed in some form by a template metaprogram prior to runtime
computers runtime see also generic and template metaprogramming objects c introduces some object oriented oo features to c it offers classes which
computers which provide the four features commonly present in oo and some non oo languages abstraction encapsulation inheritance and polymorphism objects are
computers are set by classes which are basically like a set of attributes already defined and can be created at any time
computers time encapsulation encapsulation is the grouping together of data and functionality c implements encapsulation by allowing all members of a class
computers class to be declared as either public private or protected a public member of the class will be accessible to any
computers any function a private member will only be accessible to functions that are members of that class and to functions and
computers and classes explicitly granted access permission by the class friends a protected member will be accessible to members of classes that
computers that inherit from the class in addition to the class itself and any friends the oo principle is that all and
computers and only the functions that can access the internal representation of a type should be encapsulated within the type definition c
computers c supports this via member functions and friend functions but does not enforce it the programmer can declare parts or all
computers all of the representation of a type to be public and is also allowed to make public entities that are not
computers not part of the representation of the type because of this c supports not just oo programming but other weaker decomposition
computers decomposition paradigms like modular programming it is generally considered good practice to make all data private or protected and to make
computers make public only those functions that are part of a minimal interface for users of the class that hides implementation details
computers details inheritance inheritance allows one data type to acquire properties of other data types inheritance from a base class may be
computers be declared as public protected or private this access specifier determines whether unrelated and derived classes can access the inherited public
computers public and protected members of the base class only public inheritance corresponds to what is usually meant by inheritance the other
computers other two forms are much less frequently used if the access specifier is omitted inheritance is assumed to be private for
computers for a class base and public for a struct base base classes may be declared as virtual this is called virtual
computers virtual inheritance virtual inheritance ensures that only one instance of a base class exists in the inheritance graph avoiding some of
computers of the ambiguity problems of multiple inheritance multiple inheritance is a c feature sometimes considered controversial multiple inheritance allows a class
computers class to be derived from more than one base class this can result in a complicated graph of inheritance relationships for
computers for example a flying cat class can inherit from both cat and flying mammal some other languages such as c or
computers or java accomplish something similar although more limited by allowing inheritance of multiple interfaces while restricting the number of base classes
computers classes to one interfaces unlike classes provide only declarations of member functions no implementation or member data polymorphism see also polymorphism
computers polymorphism in object oriented programming polymorphism computer science enables one common interface for many implementations and for objects to act different
computers different under different circumstances c supports several kinds of static compile time and dynamic run time polymorphism compile time polymorphism does
computers does not allow for certain run time decisions while run time polymorphism typically incurs a performance penalty static polymorphism function overloading
computers overloading function overloading allows programs to declare multiple functions with the same name the functions are distinguished by the number and
computers and or types of their formal parameters thus the same function name can refer to different functions depending on the context
computers context in which it is used the type returned by the function is not used to distinguish overloaded functions operator overloading
computers overloading similarly operator overloading allows programs to define certain operators such as lt or amp to result in a function call
computers call that depends on the types of the operands they are used on class and function templates templates in c provide
computers provide a sophisticated mechanism for writing generic polymorphic code in particular through the curiously recurring template pattern it s possible to
computers to implement a form of static polymorphism that closely mimics the syntax for overriding virtual methods a dynamic polymorphism technique described
computers described below since c templates are type aware and turing complete they can also be used to let the compiler resolve
computers resolve recursive conditionals and generate substantial programs through template metaprogramming dynamic polymorphism polymorphism through inheritance variable pointers and references of a
computers a base class type in c can refer to objects of any derived classes of that type in addition to objects
computers objects exactly matching the variable type this allows arrays and other kinds of containers to hold pointers to objects of differing
computers differing types because assignment of values to variables usually occurs at run time this is necessarily a run time phenomenon c
computers c also provides a dynamic cast operator which allows the program to safely attempt conversion of an object into an object
computers object of a more specific object type as opposed to conversion to a more general type which is always allowed this
computers this feature relies on run time type information rtti objects known to be of a certain specific type can also be
computers be cast to that type with static cast a purely compile time construct which is faster and does not require rtti
computers rtti virtual member functions through virtual member functions different objects that share a common base class may all support an operation
computers operation in different ways the member functions implemented by the derived class are said to override the same member functions of
computers of the base class in contrast with function overloading the parameters for a given member function are always exactly the same
computers same in number and type only the type of the object for which this method is called varies in addition to
computers to standard member functions operator overloads and destructors can also be virtual by virtue of inherited objects being polymorphic it may
computers may not be possible for the compiler to determine the type of the object at compile time the decision is therefore
computers therefore put off until runtime and is called dynamic dispatch in this way the most specific implementation of the function is
computers is called according to the actual run time type of the object in c this is commonly done using virtual function
computers function tables this may sometimes be bypassed by prepending a fully qualified class name before the function call but calls to
computers to virtual functions are in general always resolved at run time this example program makes use of virtual functions polymorphism and
computers and inheritance to derive new more specific objects from a base class in this case the base class is a bird
computers bird and the more specific swan is made parsing and processing c source code it is relatively difficult to write a
computers a good c parser with classic parsing algorithms such as lalr see this is partly because the c grammar is not
computers not lalr because of this there are very few tools for analyzing or performing non trivial transformations e g refactoring of
computers of existing code one way to handle this difficulty is to choose a different syntax such as significantly prettier and easier
computers easier c syntax which is lalr parseable parsing in the literal sense of producing a syntax tree is not the most
computers most difficult problem in building a c processing tool such tools must also have the same understanding of the meaning of
computers of the identifiers in the program as a compiler might have practical systems for processing c must then not only parse
computers parse the source text but be able to resolve for each identifier precisely which identifier definition applies e g correctly handle
computers handle c s complex scoping rules but must also be able to determine the type of each identifer and expression finally
computers finally a practical c processing tool must be able to handle the variety of c dialects used in practice gnu microsoft
computers microsoft but also implement appropriate analyzers source code transformers and regenerate source text combining advanced parsing algorithms such as glr with
computers with symbol table construction and program transformation machinery can enable the construction of arbitrary c tools problems and controversies c has
computers has been the subject of debate traditionally c compilers have had a range of problems the c standard does not cover
computers cover implementation of name mangling exception handling and other implementation specific features making object code produced by different compilers incompatible there
computers there are however third party standards for particular machines or operating systems which attempt to standardize compilers on those platforms for
computers for example c abi some compilers adopt a secondary standard for these items for many years different c compilers implemented the

computers debugged it and obtained an interpreter for lisp programs in s expression form people could then enter program code as s
computers s expression test it and not have to worry anymore about the tedious error prone process of translating programs manually into
computers into machine code thus was started the tradition of using the data syntax subset for writing actual code so as to
computers to use a very useful metaprogram the interpreter itself made possible by the universal nature of the language the m expression
computers expression survived for some time at least in paper documentation and usage m now stood for meta more so than for
computers for mathematical because it was used in the metalanguage of lisp but in the end the use of the data syntax
computers syntax stuck because it was found to be actually more natural just what is so great about having a data syntax
computers syntax for code the ability to easily write metaprograms that is programs that manipulate other programs by seamlessly turning data into
computers into code and code into data this makes it easy to experiment with variants and extensions of the language whereas lisp
computers lisp started as kind of a functional programming language it could and did easily absorb imperative programming structured programming object oriented
computers oriented programming graphical user interfaces pattern matching logic distributed dynamic web applications etc as soon as someone somewhere invented any feasible
computers feasible paradigm said paradigm could easily be imported into lisp whereas a non lisper inventor of some idea would maybe with
computers with a lot of effort after many years build a full fledged language from scratch around his one paradigm lispers could
computers could with comparatively little incremental effort support the same paradigm as the extension of a one environment that also supported all
computers all the previously invented paradigms and that would also support all the future paradigms whenever these would be invented and of
computers of course while experimenting lispers are not limited to an all or nothing approach of language selection but can explore all
computers all kinds of language features and ways to combine them and get an actual running language implementation for each combination for
computers for instance while experimenting with the scheme dialect of lisp steele and sussman were reportedly writing as many as ten interpreters
computers interpreters a week by contrast non lispers may require weeks s or years between each actually tested iteration of their language
computers language design process this allows lisp to benefit from a language design experience beyond anything that has ever been tried with
computers with any other programming language lisp was the only intrinsically programmable programming language now just any universal programming language can be
computers be encoded so that code can be included and manipulated as data by programs in the same language and indeed most
computers most serious programming languages end up being implemented by a compiler in same language after a phase of bootstrap from a
computers a different metalanguage using the very same technique used with lisp between and in any case any language implementation supposes that
computers that a mechanism is provided by which programs can be practically encoded as data if only as a data stream from
computers from user input to be directly interpreted or compiled without intermediate representation thus any language is at least in theory and
computers and at least in some contorted practical way fit for metaprogramming however lisp still possesses quite an edge in this regard
computers regard which is intimately tied to its very distinctive characteristic the encoding of code as nested lists of symbols and other
computers other data firstly this encoding of code as data is well defined as part of the language itself this means that
computers that there is a common standard representation that serves as the basis for development of metaprograms by anyone by contrast in
computers in other languages every would be metaprogrammer has to start from scratch and sharing his metacode with other people will be
computers be hampered because encoding is implementation dependent subject to changes restricted by intellectual property barriers etc this restrains considerably the potential
computers potential for human collaboration about metaprograms secondly the lisp encoding of code as nested lists is very simple and powerful the
computers the choice of a single universal and versatile data structure means that it is very easy to write metaprograms both from
computers from lisp and to lisp as said alan perlis it is better to have functions operate on one data structure than
computers than functions on data structures the overhead for writing metaprograms in lisp is thus very low as compared to what you
computers you have in about any other language there is opportunity for writing code that is both shorter and more widely applicable
computers applicable than in other languages less expensive and more valuable thirdly the natural mapping between the nested list structure of code
computers code as data and the semantics of said code also contribute to making metaprogramming simple the recursive evaluation model where all
computers all expressions yield values makes it much simpler to manipulate programs than the common dual statements vs expressions model found in
computers in most other languages more generally the lisp grammar has two non terminals pairs and atoms where other languages commonly have
computers have a lot of non terminals that lead to a combinatorial explosion for metaprograms the ability to locally define lexical dynamic
computers dynamic and syntactic bindings as well as higher order functions method combinations and many other features also allow for local code
computers code transformations to be much more expressive than they could possibly be in other languages where the same effects would require
computers require global program rewrite lisp code can thus be factored in much nicer ways than code in other languages fourthly because
computers because lisp code can be compiled efficiently and dynamically it is not only easy but also efficient to use lisp as
computers as the target for metaprograms in other languages people have to use slow interpreters or to target special purpose virtual machines
computers machines when generating code dynamically because dynamic production linkage and execution of code is so difficult interestingly technical difficulties with these
computers these languages can often be overcome at the price of bulk slowness unsafety and various limitations but intellectual property restrictions on
computers on the availability and use of the compiler and linker make these techniques impossible to use on the mainstream of computers
computers computers running proprietary systems with mainstream languages quasiquotation allows one to easily write templates of data including most particularly code representation
computers representation where part of the structure is fixed whereas other parts are computed the syntax is almost the same as for
computers for quoted data except for unquotes at places where the structure is not fixed and computation is to happen quasiquotes can
computers can be nested which allows for meta meta programs or meta n programs interestingly quasiquotation is a concept independent from the
computers the actual representation of programs it helps abstract away from the fact that programs be encoded as lists or otherwise it
computers it gets even better when it can be used for matching code as well as for generating code lists are still
computers still useful though and so are straight quotes in combination with quasiquotes lists allow to handle the variable part of program
computers program patterns and quotes are instrumental in distinguishing levels of nested unquotation thus it is unclear whether use of quasiquotation in
computers in other languages matches the utility of quasiquotation in lisp a notable exception is slate which with tagged quasiquotation can do
computers do unquotation in a clearer and more powerful way than is possible in straight lisp though lisp can be extended to
computers to match this feature also interestingly the discovery of quasiquotation and the power unleashed by nesting it and combining it with
computers with quote is tied to the existence of quote and hence to the specifically lispy tradition of a separate data syntax
computers syntax last but not least the lisp language also includes a lot of reflective infrastructure from boundp to get setf expander
computers expander to the clos mop that allows one to write language extensions that take advantage of each other instead of being
computers being mutually incompatible as happens in so many other languages in any mainstream language language extension implies having mutually incompatible new
computers new compilers for each set of new features by contrast language extension in lisp is a matter of using components that
computers that most of the time interoperate out of the box you may have to ensure that globally rewriting metaprograms are run
computers run in the right order but this is intrinsic to the problem of combining such metaprograms and the infrastructure of lisp
computers lisp makes such problems far less frequent than in other languages the worst you usually have to do is to ensure
computers ensure that symbols are interned in the right package in conclusion unlike most other languages lisp is not an arbitrary design
computers design based on the whims of some author but it is a discovery produced by a long evolution and a deep
computers deep tradition it has seen several revolutions transition from m expression to s expression from evalquote to eval or from dynamic
computers dynamic binding to static binding introduction of data structures of object oriented programming and of a meta object protocol the invention
computers invention and latter standardization of many many individual features many dialects of lisp also introduce their own revolutions such as continuations
computers continuations and single name space in scheme the graphical user interface and dreaded dwim features in interlisp etc if anything remains
computers remains among all these revolutions and variants it is the ability to evolve lisp is a language fit for evolution not
computers not just by a small group of wizards who control the language implementation but by every single programmer who uses the
computers the language and this wasn t a conscious intended part of the original design this was the great discovery of lisp

computers lisp scheme c program programming computer programming often shortened to programming is a process that leads from an original formulation of
computers of a computing problem to executable programs it involves activities such as analysis understanding and generically solving such problems resulting in
computers in an algorithm verification of requirements of the algorithm including its correctness and its resource consumption implementation commonly referred to as
computers as coding of the algorithm in a target programming language testing debugging and maintaining the source code implementation of the build
computers build system and management of derived artefacts such as machine code of computer programs the algorithm is often only represented in
computers in human parsable form and reasoned about using logic source code is in one or more programming languages such as c
computers c c c java python smalltalk javascript etc the purpose of programming is to find a sequence of instructions that will
computers will automate performing a specific task or solve a given problem the process of programming thus often requires expertise in many
computers many different subjects including knowledge of the application domain specialized algorithms and formal logic within software engineering programming the implementation is
computers is regarded as one phase in a software development process there is an on going debate on the extent to which
computers which the writing of programs is an art form a craft or an engineering discipline in general good programming is considered
computers considered to be the measured application of all three with the goal of producing an efficient and evolvable software solution the
computers the criteria for efficient and evolvable vary considerably the discipline differs from many other technical professions in that programmers in general
computers general do not need to be licensed or pass any standardized or governmentally regulated certification tests in order to call themselves
computers themselves programmers or even software engineers because the discipline covers many areas which may or may not include critical applications it
computers it is debatable whether licensing is required for the profession as a whole in most cases the discipline is self governed
computers governed by the entities which require the programming and sometimes very strict environments are defined e g united states air force
computers force use of adacore and security clearance however representing oneself as a professional software engineer without a license from an accredited
computers accredited institution is illegal in many parts of the world another on going debate is the extent to which the programming
computers programming language used in writing computer programs affects the form that the final program citation needed this debate is analogous to
computers to that surrounding the sapir whorf hypothesis in linguistics and cognitive science which the first step in most formal software development
computers development processes is requirements analysis ed by testing to determine value modeling implementation and failure elimination debugging there exist a lot
computers lot of differing approaches for each of those tasks one approach popular for requirements analysis is use case analysis many programmers
computers programmers use forms of agile software development where the various stages of formal software development are more integrated together into short
computers short cycles that take a few weeks rather than years there are many approaches to the software development process popular modeling
computers modeling techniques include object oriented analysis and design ooad and model driven architecture mda the unified modeling language uml is a
computers a notation used for both the ooad and mda a similar technique used for database design is entity relationship modeling er
computers er modeling implementation techniques include imperative languages object oriented or procedural functional languages and logic languages pseudocode adding new commands iteration

economics the austrian school also known as the vienna school or the psychological school is a schools of economic thought school of
economics of economic thought that emphasizes the spontaneous organizing power of the price mechanism austrians hold that the complexity of subjective human
economics human choices makes mathematical modelling of the evolving market extremely difficult or undecidable and advocate a laissez faire approach to the
economics the economy austrian school economists advocate the strict enforcement of voluntary contractual agreements between economic agents and hold that commercial transactions
economics transactions should be subject to the smallest possible imposition of forces they consider to be in particular the smallest possible amount
economics amount of government intervention the austrian school derives its name from its predominantly austrian founders and early supporters including carl menger
economics menger eugen von b hm bawerk and ludwig von mises other prominent austrian school economists of the th century include henry
economics henry hazlitt murray rothbard and nobel memorial prize in economic sciences nobel laureate friedrich hayek the austrian school of economics peter
economics peter j boettke though called austrian today supporters and proponents of the austrian school can come from any part of the
economics the world the austrian school was influential in the early th century and was for a time considered by many to
economics to be part of mainstream economics austrian contributions to mainstream economic thought include being one of the main influences in the
economics the development of the marginalist theory of value including the subjective theory of value on which it is based as well
economics well as contributions to the economic calculation debate which concerns the allocative properties of a centrally planned economy versus a decentralized
economics decentralized free market economy jack birner rudy van zijp hayek co ordination and evolution routledge p from the middle of the
economics the th century onwards it has been considered a heterodox school name boettke and name austrian economists boettke and currently contributes
economics contributes relatively little to mainstream economic thought however some assertions of austrian school economists have been interpreted by some as warnings
economics warnings about the financial crisis of financial crisis the fed s modus operandi panic by steve h hanke which has in
economics in turn led to renewed interest in the school s theories economic lessons from lenin s seer kyle crichton feb nytimes
economics nytimes austrian school economists advocate strict adherence to methodological individualism which they describe as analyzing human action from the perspective of
economics of individual agent austrian school economists argue that the only means of arriving at a valid economic theory is to derive
economics derive it logically from basic principles of human action a method called praxeology this method holds that it allows for the
economics the discovery of fundamental economic laws valid for all human action alongside praxeology these theories traditionally advocated an interpretive approach to
economics to history to address specific historical events the interpretive turn don lavoie additionally whereas mainstream economists often utilize natural experiments austrian
economics austrian economists contend that experimental in economics is virtually impossible since it relies on human actors who cannot be placed in
economics in a lab setting without altering their would be actions mainstream economists believe that the methodology adopted by modern austrian economics
economics economics lacks scientific rigor more than anything else what prevents austrian economists from getting more publications in mainstream journals is that
economics that their papers rarely use mathematics or econometrics research tools that austrians reject on principle austrian economics and the mainstream view
economics view from the boundary by roger e backhouse hayek did not fall out of favor because he was not keynesian neither
economics neither are friedman or lucas but because he was perceived to be doing neither rigorous theory nor empirical work critics have
economics have argued that the austrian approach fails the test of why we can t associate too closely with the austrians history
economics history classical economics focused on the labour theory of value which holds that the value of a commodity is equal to
economics to the amount of labour required to produce it in the late th century however attention was focused on the concepts
economics concepts of marginal cost and value the austrian school was one of three founding currents of the marginal revolution the marginal
economics marginal revolution of the s with its major contribution being the introduction of the approach in economics carl menger s book
economics book principles of economics was the catalyst for this development while marginalism was generally influential there was also a more specific
economics specific school that grew up around menger which came to be known as the school vienna school or austrian school israel
economics israel m kirzner austrian school of economics the new palgrave a dictionary of economics economics is the social science that analyzes
economics analyzes the production distribution and consumption of goods and services political economy was the earlier name for the subject but economists
economics economists in the late th century suggested economics as a shorter term for economic science that also avoided a narrow political
economics political interest connotation and as similar in form to mathematics ethics and so forth a focus of the subject is how
economics how economic agents behave or interact and how economies work consistent with this a primary textbook distinction is between microeconomics and
economics and macroeconomics microeconomics examines the behavior of basic elements in the economy including individual agents such as households and firms or
economics or as buyers and sellers and markets and their interactions macroeconomics analyzes the entire economy and issues affecting it including unemployment
economics unemployment inflation economic growth and monetary and fiscal policy other broad distinctions include those between positive economics describing what is and
economics and normative economics advocating what ought to be between economic theory and applied economics between rational and behavioral economics and between
economics between mainstream economics more orthodox and dealing with the rationality individualism equilibrium nexus and heterodox economics more radical and dealing with
economics with the institutions history social structure nexus economic analysis may be applied throughout society as in business finance health care and
economics and government but also to such diverse subjects as crime education the family law politics religion social institutions war and science
economics science at the turn of the st century the expanding domain of economics in the social sciences has been described as
economics as economic imperialism an increasing number of economists have called for increased emphasis on environmental sustainability this area of research is
economics is known as ecological economics microeconomics economic development markets production cost and efficiency specialization supply and demand firms uncertainty and game
economics game theory market failure public sector macroeconomics growth business cycle unemployment inflation and monetary policy fiscal policy international economics practice theory

economics structure such that no participants are large enough to have the market power to set the price of a homogeneous product
economics product another way of putting this is to say a perfectly competitive market exists when every participant is a price taker
economics taker and no participant influences the price of the product it buys or sells imperfect competition refers to market structures where
economics where the conditions of perfect competition do not exist forms of imperfect competition include monopoly in which there is only one
economics one seller of a good duopoly in which there are only two sellers of a good oligopoly in which there are
economics are few sellers of a good monopolistic competition in which there are many sellers producing highly differentiated goods monopsony in which
economics which there is only one buyer of a good and oligopsony in which there are few buyers of a good unlike

economics inputs may include intermediate goods used in production of final goods such as the steel in a new car economic efficiency
economics efficiency describes how well a system generates desired output with a given set of inputs and available technology efficiency is improved
economics improved if more output is generated without changing inputs or in other words the amount of waste is reduced a widely
economics widely accepted general standard is pareto efficiency which is reached when no further change can make someone better off without making
economics making someone else worse off an example ppf with illustrative points marked the production possibility frontier ppf is an expository figure
economics figure for representing scarcity cost and efficiency in the simplest case an economy can produce just two goods say guns and
economics and butter the ppf is a table or graph as at the right showing the different quantity combinations of the two
economics two goods producible with a given technology and total factor inputs which limit feasible total output each point on the curve
economics curve shows potential total output for the economy which is the maximum feasible output of one good given a feasible output
economics output quantity of the other good scarcity is represented in the figure by people being willing but unable in the aggregate
economics aggregate to consume beyond the ppf such as at x and by the negative slope of the curve if production of
economics of one good increases along the curve production of the other good decreases an inverse relationship this is because increasing output
economics output of one good requires transferring inputs to it from production of the other good decreasing the latter the slope of
economics of the curve at a point on it gives the trade off between the two goods it measures what an additional

economics thus if one more gun costs units of butter the opportunity cost of one gun is butter along the ppf scarcity
economics scarcity implies that choosing more of one good in the aggregate entails doing with less of the other good still in

economics by these externalities elementary demand and supply theory predicts equilibrium but not the speed of adjustment for changes of equilibrium due

economics endogenous growth models and in growth accounting business cycle main article business cycle see also circular flow of income aggregate supply
economics supply aggregate demand unemployment and great depression the economics of a depression were the spur for the creation of macroeconomics as
economics as a separate discipline field of study during the great depression of the s john maynard keynes authored a book entitled
economics entitled the general theory of employment interest and money outlining the key theories of keynesian economics keynes contended that aggregate demand
economics demand for goods might be insufficient during economic downturns leading to unnecessarily high unemployment and losses of potential output he therefore
economics therefore advocated active policy responses by the public sector including monetary policy actions by the central bank and fiscal policy actions
economics actions by the government to stabilize output over the business cycle thus a central conclusion of keynesian economics is that in
economics in some situations no strong automatic mechanism moves output and employment towards full employment levels john hicks is lm model has
economics has been the most influential interpretation of the general theory over the years understanding of the business cycle has branched into
economics into various research programs mostly related to or distinct from keynesianism the neoclassical synthesis refers to the reconciliation of keynesian economics
economics economics with neoclassical economics stating that keynesianism is correct in the short run but qualified by neoclassical like considerations in the
economics the intermediate and long run new classical macroeconomics as distinct from the keynesian view of the business cycle posits market clearing
economics clearing with imperfect information it includes friedman s permanent income hypothesis on consumption and rational expectations theory lead by robert lucas
economics lucas and real business cycle theory in contrast the new keynesian approach retains the rational expectations assumption however it assumes a
economics a variety of market failures in particular new keynesians assume prices and wages are sticky which means they do not adjust
economics adjust instantaneously to changes in economic conditions thus the new classicals assume that prices and wages adjust automatically to attain full
economics full employment whereas the new keynesians see full employment as being automatically achieved only in the long run and hence government
economics government and central bank policies are needed because the long run may be very long unemployment main article unemployment percent of
economics of us population employed the amount of unemployment in an economy is measured by the unemployment rate the percentage of workers
economics workers without jobs in the labour force the labour force only includes workers actively looking for jobs people who are retired
economics retired pursuing education or discouraged from seeking work by a lack of job prospects are excluded from the labor force unemployment
economics unemployment can be generally broken down into several types that are related to different causes classical unemployment occurs when wages are
economics are too high for employers to be willing to hire more workers wages may be too high because of minimum wage
economics wage laws or union activity consistent with classical unemployment frictional unemployment occurs when appropriate job vacancies exist for a worker but
economics but the length of time needed to search for and find the job leads to a period of unemployment structural unemployment
economics unemployment covers a variety of possible causes of unemployment including a mismatch between workers skills and the skills required for open
economics open jobs large amounts of structural unemployment can occur when an economy is transitioning industries and workers find their previous set
economics set of skills are no longer in demand structural unemployment is similar to frictional unemployment since both reflect the problem of
economics of matching workers with job vacancies but structural unemployment covers the time needed to acquire new skills not just the short
economics short term search process while some types of unemployment may occur regardless of the condition of the economy cyclical unemployment occurs
economics occurs when growth stagnates okun s law represents the empirical relationship between unemployment and economic growth the original version of okun
economics okun s law states that a increase in output would lead to a decrease in unemployment inflation and monetary policy main
economics main articles inflation and monetary policy see also money quantity theory of money monetary policy and history of money money is
economics is a means of final payment for goods in most price system economies and the unit of account in which prices

economics money does money has a general acceptability a relative consistency in value divisibility durability portability elastic in supply and survives with
economics with mass public confidence it includes currency held by the nonbank public and checkable deposits it has been described as a
economics a social convention like language useful to one largely because it is useful to others the federal reserve sets monetary policy
economics policy as the central bank of the united states as a medium of exchange money facilitates trade it is essentially a
economics a measure of value and more importantly a store of value being a basis for credit creation its economic function can
economics can be contrasted with barter non monetary exchange given a diverse array of produced goods and specialized producers barter may entail
economics entail a hard to locate double coincidence of wants as to what is exchanged say apples and a book money can
economics can reduce the transaction cost of exchange because of its ready acceptability then it is less costly for the seller to
economics to accept money in exchange rather than what the buyer produces at the level of an economy theory and evidence are
economics are consistent with a positive relationship running from the total money supply to the nominal value of total output and to
economics to the general price level for this reason management of the money supply is a key aspect of monetary policy fiscal
economics fiscal policy main articles fiscal policy and government spending governments implement fiscal policy by adjusting spending and taxation policies to alter
economics alter aggregate demand when aggregate demand falls below the potential output of the economy there is an output gap where some
economics some productive capacity is left unemployed governments increase spending and cut taxes to boost aggregate demand resources that have been idled
economics idled can be used by the government for example unemployed home builders can be hired to expand highways tax cuts allow
economics allow consumers to increase their spending which boosts aggregate demand both tax cuts and spending have multiplier effects where the initial
economics initial increase in demand from the policy percolates through the economy and generates additional economic activity the effects of fiscal policy
economics policy can be limited by crowding out when there is no output gap the economy is producing at full capacity and
economics and there are no excess productive resources if the government increases spending in this situation the government use resources that otherwise
economics otherwise would have been used by the private sector so there is no increase in overall output some economists think that
economics that crowding out is always an issue while others do not think it is a major issue when output is depressed
economics depressed skeptics of fiscal policy also make the argument of ricardian equivalence they argue that an increase in debt will have
economics have to be paid for with future tax increases which will cause people to reduce their consumption and save money to
economics to pay for the future tax increase under ricardian equivalence any boost in demand from fiscal policy will be offset by
economics by the increased savings rate intended to pay for future higher taxes international economics main articles international economics and economic system
